awd_titl_txt: Field Monitoring and Measurements Education: A Model for Civil and Environmental Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of New Orleans (UNO), Louisiana State University (LSU) and the Louisiana Transportation Research Center (LTRC) are partnering on the project "Field Monitoring and Measurements Education: A Model for Civil and Environmental Engineering."   The goal of this project is to develop a model instructional program, using structural engineering and structural health monitoring as a test bed, that can be used to educate civil and environmental engineering (CEE) students in the fundamental principles and technology of field monitoring and measurements (FMM) and to utilize monitoring technologies and FMM data to evaluate performance and behavior, analyze problems and design CEE systems.  The nation's aging, and in some cases, failing infrastructure necessitates the education of future engineers to address problems related to structural health (and other critical areas).  Since this project addresses a national need, two activities will be given significant attention: developing and implementing the instructional materials in a manner that maximizes their potential for adoption at other institutions; and building a community of interested and contributing scholars. The latter effort will encompass targeted proactive outreach activities at the state, regional, and national levels. 

Specific objectives of the project are to: (1) improve student performance with respect to the existing learning outcomes of the civil engineering courses into which field monitoring modules will be incorporated, (2) improve student knowledge of and ability to use field monitoring measurements, (3) train faculty in the use of the curricular materials and (4) develop a community of scholars that has an interest in and will contribute to the further development of FMM instructional materials.  Quality control and quality assurance of the instructional materials will be achieved through close coordination among the investigators, the advisory panel, and the external evaluator aided by the results of a formative evaluation of the prototype structural engineering FMM instructional unit and a summative evaluation of a revised unit over a two academic year cycle at both LSU and UNO. During the second year of the project, the unit will be introduced and assessed at four partner institutions (Virginia Tech, Case Western Reserve University, Tuskegee University and University of North Florida). The project collaborators at the partner institutions will also be used in an advisory capacity throughout all stages of the project. The results of this project will serve to establish an instructional model upon which other CEE sub-disciplines can build.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this project is to develop and disseminate a model instructional program -- using structural engineering as the specific discipline within civil and environmental engineering (CEE) -- that can be used to educate CEE students in the fundamental principles and technology of field monitoring and measurement (FMM) and to utilize monitoring technologies and FMM data to analyze, design, and evaluate the performance and behavior of CEE systems. The specific FMM technology selected to validate the efficacy of this approach within the practice of structural engineering was Structural Health Monitoring (SHM).

 

Specific education pedagogy and technical content were developed to effectively and efficiently introduce one example of Field Monitoring and Measurements (FMM) technology, specifically Structural Health Monitoring (SHM), into the undergraduate Civil and Environmental Engineering curriculum. The technical content is embodied in the SHM Education Unit, a comprehensive education scheme consisting of nine education modules encompassing both fundamentals and applications.

 

The Structural Health Monitoring Education (SHM) Unit encompasses two subunits- the SHM Fundamentals Education Subunit and the SHM Applications Education Subunit.  In order to meet the learning objectives of the Subunits, five fundamentals education modules and four applications education modules were developed, implemented, assessed and revised.  A comprehensive guide for planning and implementation of the SHM Education Unit was prepared and posted on the FMM Home Page for the use of new adopters.  A model and testing protocol were developed to demonstrate SHM monitoring methodology and equipment.  The investigators developed a comprehensive web site whose gateway- the FMM Home Page- that provides access to background information, scholarly papers, faculty instructional resources, student education resource, the Planning and Implementation Guide, and a video based explanation of the SHM Education Unit and its implementation.  An explanatory brochure was distributed to CEE departments nationally inviting faculty to adopt and adapt the SHM Education Unit at their institution.

 

In addition to the five fundamentals education modules and the four applications education modules, the website includes readiness exams, discussion questions and surveys to facilitate an instructor’s implementation of the education modules in the class.  The web-based presentation of the Planning and Implementation Guide together with a video to demonstrate the application of the instrumentation for structural health monitoring in the field will be particularly helpful to the instructors implementing the education modules. 

 

The SHM Education Unit provides an effective and efficient means for CEE departments and faculty to introduce a topic to students in an underserved area of the undergraduate curriculum- Field Monitoring and Measurements. Given the extensive content contained within the Unit, it could be adapted and supplemented if necessary for use in advanced undergraduate and professional development courses. Further, the Unit is conceivably adaptable for use in other engineering disciplines other than civil and environmental engineering.

 

The results have been disseminated to the education and technical communities via papers published by the American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) and a workshop conducted at the ISHMll International Conference in St Louis, MO. Direct mailings to departments of civil and environmental engineering have been used to inform departmental chairs and faculty of the existence of the SHM Education Unit and the resources available to introduce the Unit at their institution.

 

Given the voluntary adoption of the SHM Education Unit by other institutions nationally, students will not only be given specific insight and knowledge about the purpose, methods and equipment of Structural Health Monitoring but more broadly about the importance of field monitoring and measurements to civil and environmental engineering professional practice.

 

The principles and practices of field monitoring and measurements (FMM) have application across most fields of engineering and science. Thus, the education model developed as a result of the project could easily be adapted for introduction of applicable FMM content in other undergraduate engineering and science curricula.

 

Given the potential for wide acceptance and implementation of the SHM Education Unit by civil and environmental engineering programs nationally, some students could pursue additional SHM studies and potentially focus their professional careers in the field of structural health monitoring. Better and increased use of field monitoring and measurements technologies will contribute to the improved performance, reduced cost and increased safety of the civil infrastructure.

 

The health restrictions imposed by the COVID pandemic basically prevented the implementation of the planned face-to-face webinar series. In the absence of that possibility, the Principal Investigators enhanced the content of the SHM Education Unit Planning and Implementation Guide, produced a video version of the planned webinar, and made it accessible from FMM Project Home Page.
